text: Kevin drew the following graph to help him find the number of cakes sold to make a profit.
• Explain how Kevin could use his graph to determine Fabian’s profit.
Kevin can find when Fabian’s expenses and income are approximately equal. Where the lines intersect, we know that Fabian will make $0. After that, he will begin to make a profit.
• Kevin highlighted the vertical distance –330 between the two graphs. What does the –330 represent on the graph? What does it represent in the real world?
The 330 shows that the value of E is higher than I. In the real world, this shows that Fabian will spend $330 more in expenses than he will earn when he sells 100 cakes.
• Adia claims she can find the coordinates of the point of intersection by solving the equation, 8.20n = 825 + 3.25n. Is this possible? Explain. How does it help?

This is possible because (8.20n) represents the income and (825 + 3.25n) represents the expenses. So, by solving this equation, you are finding the point when income and expenses are equal, or where the two lines intersect.
• If Kevin sells 125 cakes, is he losing or making money? Explain why.
Losing. Looking at the graphs, Income (pink line) is lower than the Expenses (blue line) until after 150 cakes. So, he will lose money until he sells more than 150 cakes.
• Fabian uses the equation P = Income – Expenses to predict the profit. He wrote P = 8.20n – (825 + 3.25n). Does this make sense? Explain.
Yes, since he wants to subtract expenses from income for a given number of cakes, he can subtract the expenses expression from the income expression to give an expression for overall profit.
• Adia rewrites Fabian’s profit equation as P = 4.95n – 825. Is she correct? Explain.
Yes, this equation will give the same result as Fabian’s. Her equation gives the profit for each cake and subtracts the fixed, monthly expenses.

Situation C. Fabian’s Profit Inequality

Fabian and Billie are looking for ways to express how express how to find the number of cakes needed to make a profit. Explain why each representation does or does not make sense.

The inequality statement does make sense, because it says that they want their profit to be greater than their income – expenses. The number line does make sense because it shows all possible values of n for which they have a profit.
